quote: I like to cook all kinds of stuff.   Like yogurt and raisin salad...   chocolate-chip pancakes... and   purple omelettes.
Purple omelettes?
You put grape juice in the eggs.   Isabella doesn't like it very much   -- she says it tastes funny.
I can see her point...
Sugar with your tea?
Yes, please.
Isabella... would you like some   too?
Yes. But she takes two cubes.
I'll bet Isabella is very pretty.
She's very, very pretty. She has   blonde hair and a blue dress with   white buttons. Her ears are   pierced. And she's tall.
Maybe you could draw me a picture.   I'd love to see what she looks   like.
You don't think she's real.
I think she's real for you, Clara.   And that's real enough for me.
Honey, I think it's time for you   to go. You don't want to keep   Keiko waiting.
I have to go plant the nasturtiums   now.       I'm Keiko's helper in the   arboretum today.
Is that so?
Go ahead, Sweetie. Be home for   dinner.
I hope to see you soon, Clara.   Maybe we can be friends.
Okay.
Counselor Troi?
Yes?
Isabella says she likes you.
Thank you, Isabella.
I understand why you're   concerned... but you have nothing   to worry about. It's a normal,   healthy activity for children to   engage in imaginary play.
I'm just afraid she's not making   real friends. She spends all of   her time with "Isabella"...

You've been moving from starship   to starship since Clara was two   years old. Maybe Isabella   provides a constant companion for   Clara. She knows this is one   friend she won't have to leave   behind.
You're probably right.
Give Clara a chance. As she   learns to make friends on the   Enterprise, she'll probably move   away from her imaginary world.
Captain's log, stardate 45852.1.   The Enterprise has arrived at   FGC-four-seven -- a nebula which   has formed around a neutron star.   We are eager to investigate this   unique formation.
We've got elevated quantities of   hydrogen... helium... trionium...   but nothing the shields can't   handle.
Shields up.
Take us in, Ensign. One-quarter   impulse.
Aye, sir.
In order to complete the scheduled   observations, the lateral sensors   will require additional processing   time.
We could steal a couple of hours   while they're recalibrating the   thermal interferometery scanner.
Will a couple of hours be enough   time to complete the   high-resolution series on the   neutron star?
No problem. We'll just double   up the main sensor bandwidth.
After dinner, then what?
We went to the holodeck and took   a walk on the Champs Elysees...
The neural scanner still seems   a bit off. Let's check the sensor   calibration...
I'll run a diagnostic...
And... ?
And?
After Paris... ?
He has shore leave next month.   He asked me to go to Risa with   him.
No problem. Nurse Davila can   cover for you.
I don't know if I'm going, Doctor.   I hear it's a very uninhibited   atmosphere. Personally, I don't   think I'm ready for that kind of   "fun."
Try to talk him into Telana Minor   instead -- they've got a cruise   down the Jokri River... the   iridescent currents are beautiful.
See, Isabella... you have to push   your finger into the soil as deep   as you can.
The baby seeds are very small...   so we mustn't give them too much   to drink.
Hello? Is somebody there?
Hello.
Isabella?
Hello, Clara.
Isabella... How come I can see   you?
Is something wrong with the way   I look?
No. I've just never seen you   before. Not for real.
Well... now you can see me for   real. Doesn't that make you   happy?
Yes... it's wonderful!
Can we go now?
We should finish planting the   seeds.
I'm tired of planting. Let's do   something else.
Like what?
Like...       I would really like to explore   the ship.
We should finish planting first.   I promised Keiko.
We can finish later. Let's go   look around.
I'd better ask my daddy.
Your daddy won't mind. We can   tell him later. Come on...
So what are we going to name this   nebula? "FGC-four-seven" just   doesn't have a nice ring to it.
Why don't we call it... "Sutter's   Cloud?"
The rotational period of the   neutron star is one point three   five seconds.
That's a bit on the long side.   Sutter -- let's see if we can get   a reading on the particle flux.
Aye, sir.
I was thinking more along the   lines of "The La Forge Nebula."   Sounds sort of majestic, don't   you think?
Based on those selections, I would   prefer FGC-four-seven.
What was that?
It felt like we hit something.
Shields have registered an impact.   But the sensors show nothing in   the vicinity.
Forward velocity is down by point   two percent. And dropping...
Engineering. Report.
Could be a problem with the   shields, Captain. We're checking   it out now.
Systems are normal, sir.
So -- did we hit something or not?
Shields say yes, sensors say no...   this is very strange...
Ensign, give me a breakdown   on shield energy conversion.   Run a spectral --
Whoa. Where did you come from?
I'm Clara Sutter.       That's my daddy.
Clara, you can't be here right   now.
But Isabella wanted to see   engineering.
I don't care what Isabella wanted   to see. Go back to our quarters   right now.
But Daddy...
Bridge to La Forge. Our speed   is still dropping.
I'm increasing power to the   impulse engines... but forward   velocity isn't consistent with   engine output.
Explanation.
It looks like something is   increasing the drag coefficient   on the ship. But we can't find   the cause...
If you can't correct it... we're   going to have to reverse course   and leave the nebula.
Give me a couple of minutes,   sir...
Clara -- now.
Sorry, Commander.
Why do you keep disappearing like   that?
The grown-ups don't think I'm   real. When they're around, I have   to be invisible.
Wait here.
The drag coefficient continues   to increase. Forward velocity has   fallen by twelve percent.
Our speed is increasing...
The ship's speed has stabilized   at one-quarter impulse.
Great, Data. What'd you do?
I did nothing, Commander.       The problem seems to have   corrected itself.
Where did you go?
There was something I had to do.
I don't have an explanation, sir.   We seemed to hit something... and   then we started losing speed.   But so far as we can tell, there's   nothing out there to hit.
Could some kind of damping field   cause us to lose velocity?
We simulated several such fields,   but were unable to reproduce the   same drag coefficient.
We also don't know why the problem   suddenly corrected itself.
It seems we're observing a unique   phenomenon... one that hasn't   been recorded before.
The question is, do we stay here   and check it out?
That may be dangerous.
Since we have experienced the   phenomenon only once, it is   impossible to estimate the risks.
I'd like to stick around a little   longer, sir... collect a sample   of the gaseous matter, see what   it tells us...
Agreed. Collect your sample,   Mister La Forge. We'll proceed   -- with caution.       Dismissed.
What's in here?
That's the door to the cargo bay.   We can't go in there.
Let's go someplace with lots of   people.
Okay.       Isabella, why are you so serious   lately?
What do you mean?
You haven't even smiled once   today.
You're my best friend, Isabella.
Why?
I don't know. Because we do   things together... and we trade   secrets.
Does everybody have a best friend?
If they're lucky. Before I had   you, I didn't have one...
Why not?
Every time I made friends with   someone... my daddy's job would   change and we'd move to a new ship.   And it takes time to make best   friends...
How long?
It depends. With you... not very   long. You always listened to me,   even when I was sad...
Clara... I'm glad we're best   friends.
Race you.
Okay.
Ready... set ... go!
This area is not designated for   children.
Are you lost?
Where are you supposed to be?
We were only playing. We're   sorry.
Return to your quarters. And we   will forget this incident.
Thank you!
Okay... I've configured the   magnetic coils to collect gaseous   matter from the nebula. Go ahead   and activate the beam emitter.
I'm setting the fractionater to   a continuous cycle...
We'll take samples from eight   random sections. That should give   us a reliable measure.
Commander...
I understand... that you had a   parent in Starfleet.
Two of them, as a matter of fact.   My father was an exozoologist...   my mother a command officer.
They must have been posted to a   lot of different assignments...

That's putting it mildly. They   were always on the move... some   of the time together, some times   separately... I never knew if   I was going to be stationed with   my dad while he studied   invertebrates in the Modean   system... or with my mom on some   outpost near the Neutral Zone.
Was that hard on you?
I don't remember it that way...
But... it must have been   disruptive if you didn't stay   in one place long enough to make   friends...

I guess there were things about   my childhood that weren't ideal...   but to me, it was like one long   adventure.       Kids are tougher than you think.   As long as they know you love   them... they can handle just   about anything life throws at   them.
Thanks, Commander.
I see... a Samarian coral fish...   with its fins unfolded...
I believe what you are seeing is   the effect of the fluid dynamic   processes inherent to large scale   motion of highly rarified gas.
No... first it was a fish... now   I see a Mintonian sailing ship...
Where?
Right there -- see how the two   swirls come up to form a mast...

I do not see it.       It is interesting that people try   to find meaningful patterns in   things that are essentially   random. I have noticed that the   images they perceive can sometimes   suggest what they are thinking   about at that particular moment.
Besides, it is clear that this   cloud formation most closely   resembles a "bunny rabbit."
I think someone's lost her way...
Hello there. Are you looking for   someone?
No... I brought Isabella to see   Ten Forward.
Well, ordinarily you're supposed   to be here with a grown-up... but   since you've brought Isabella,   you can be my guest.
Thank you.
How about two glasses of Papalla   juice... with extra bubbles.
Yes, thank you --
Just one, please. Isabella isn't   thirsty.
One juice...
You're not like the other   grown-ups.
Oh, no?
They don't think Isabella's real.
Sometimes grown-ups have a tough   time believing in things they   can't see.
Why?
Well... they tend to get very   preoccupied with grown-up things.
Like what?

Oh... like figuring out how much   fuel it takes to power this   ship... or deciding whether to   explore one star system or   another... arranging schedules,   making lists, counting inventory,   or... wondering if little girls   should go to bed at seven... or be   allowed to stay up till eight.
Their heads can get so full...   that there's no room left for the   things you and I know are important.   Like invisible friends.
(after a moment's     reflection)   If nobody else understands... how   come you do?
Maybe because when I was your age,   I had an invisible friend, too.
You did? What was she like?
It wasn't a she.
What was he like?
It wasn't a he.
It?
It was a Tarcassian razor beast.   It had dark brown fur, gold   eyes... huge spiny wings... It   could fly so fast that no one   could see it... except me.
Sounds scary.
It was... especially when it   smiled.

But the best thing about it was   that I could curl up and lie on   its furry stomach. It had the   deepest, softest purr you've ever   heard... it put me to sleep   every night...       That razor beast was a good   friend.
So is Isabella.
Hello, Clara.
Hello...
I was just talking with Clara and   Isabella.
Clara... would you and Isabella   like to take a walk with me?
I guess so.       'Bye.
See you later, Clara...   Isabella.
Clara, you haven't been on this   ship very long, so maybe you don't   know that Ten Forward is usually   for grown-ups.
I know that. I didn't want to   go. But Isabella wanted to see   it.
If Isabella is telling you to do   things you know are wrong... then   you must tell her it's not   acceptable.
I tried to. But she wouldn't   listen.
Deck thirty-two.
Would you like me to talk to   Isabella for you?
Isabella... it's not very nice   to tell Clara to do things she   isn't supposed to.
She's over here.
From now on... I want you to ask   a grown-up before you go places   that are off-limits.
What did she say?
She said...
Clara. Please tell me what   Isabella said.
She said... you better leave us   alone.
I'm a little concerned about the   turn this is taking. It seems   Clara is starting to do   inappropriate things... and she's   blaming them on Isabella.
She came into engineering today...   and said it was Isabella's idea.

I don't think it's too serious   yet. But we should make more of   an effort to get her involved with   real friends her own age.       The Children's Center is having   a ceramics class this afternoon.   Why don't I take Clara?
I think she'd like that.
I'll see if there's room left in   the class. In the meantime, make   yourself available to Clara. Let   her know she doesn't have to rely   on Isabella when she needs someone   to talk to.
Thank you, Counselor.
Are you mad at me?
I'm sorry I got you in trouble.
That's okay.
Are we still... best friends?
Here -- you can help me put this   together, if you want.
Clara... Why are grown-ups so   mean?
They're not mean -- they're just   more serious than we are.
Sometimes I wish they'd just go   away.
You do?
Yes... I don't like them.
I'm bored. Let's go back to   engineering.
We're not allowed to go there.
I thought we were best friends.
We are.
Then why won't you play with me?
I told you...
You always listen to the   grown-ups. You don't care about   me.
That's not true.
I thought we'd have fun   together, once you could really   see me. I thought you'd like   me...
Let's go to engineering, Clara.   Just for a little while. No one   will know -- it'll be our secret.   And if they find us, we'll tell   them we got lost...
Who is it?
Counselor Troi.
Hello, Clara.
Hi.
I came to ask if you'd like to   come to a ceramics class.
Can Isabella come, too?
No, Clara. We'll do something   with Isabella another day.
Well...       Okay.
Sir, as we move deeper into the   nebula, sensors indicate that   levels of helium and trionium have   continued to rise steadily
Is it anything the shields can't   handle?
No, sir, we are well within   tolerance levels --
Mister Data -- ?
Shields have registered an impact,   sir...
But sensors don't show anything   out there, right?
No, sir. There is no indication   of anything near the ship.
Forward velocity is dropping,   Captain. Down by point-four   percent.
Can we go to warp speed?
Until we determine the cause of   the drag coefficient, I would not   recommend it, sir.
Forward velocity is down by one   point one percent.
Ensign, increase power to the   impulse engines.
Aye, sir.
Impulse engines are now at full   power.
We are no longer losing speed.
Forward velocity is holding   steady. The drag coefficient is   still present, but it has   stabilized.
Bridge to Commander Riker... check   with Mister La Forge... see if   he's found anything in that matter   sample from the nebula.
On my way, sir.
Any luck?
Yeah -- take a look at this...
We tried radiating the matter   sample with just about everything   we could think of. We didn't find   anything... until we subjected   it to a high frequency warp   field...
This may be what we've been   running into...
Do you know what it is?
We think so. Now that the sensors   can read it, it seems to be a   highly cohesive form of plasma   -- like a strand of energy.
We figure this segment is just   part of a network of much larger   strands.
When these things come in contact   with our shields, it produces a   resonant effect -- and creates the   drag coefficient we've been   experiencing.
Anything like this on record?
No.
Any idea how many more of these   there might be?
No. But if we run the warp field   generators through the deflector   grid, we could radiate a field   outside the ship.
... and we'd see for ourselves.   Let's do it.
Aye.
Alexander, I thought you might   like a partner.
This is Clara Sutter. She's new   on board. Clara, meet Alexander   Rozhenko.
I'm making a cup for my father.   Wanna help?
It's alright...
You gotta put them all in a row...   like this...
Clara, would you like some clay   of your own?
I've never made a cup before.   How do you do the round part?
It's easy. Just take a big piece   of clay, and push your hand into   it...
Warp field generators are standing   by.
Captain -- we should be able to   illuminate any strands within two   thousand kilometers of the ship.
Proceed.
Initiating field generation...
Remarkable...
It is an irregular lattice   composed of approximately   forty-seven million strands of   energy.
Captain -- with this many out   there, the resonant effect on   our shields could cause a   problem...
Agreed. Ensign -- bring us about   and take us out of the nebula.
That may be difficult, sir.   I am now detecting a significant   number of strands behind us.
Do your best, Ensign.
Aye, sir.
Hot chocolate.
Computer -- list my appointment   schedule for next week.
Kryonian Tigers aren't so scary.   I saw one once.
You did?
My father took me to the zoo on   Brentalia. All the tiger did   was lick my hand. And he smelled   funny.
I think we need more water.
I'll get some.
Isabella?
Clara!
I didn't do it.
Then who did?
It was Isabella.
I don't see anybody.
She's invisible.
I worked two weeks on this. That   was really mean.
I didn't do it! I didn't!
There's no such thing as invisible   people. You're lying!
Hey!
Isabella, STOP!
Clara...
Why are you being so mean to me?   Why'd you do that to my friend?
Because you ran away from me.   You left me alone. I had to do   everything by myself...
You're scaring me.
I was going to protect you, Clara.   I liked you...
But now I don't care. Now... when   the others come... you can die   along with everyone else.
Status, Mister Data?
At our current speed, we will   clear the nebula in twelve   minutes, four seconds.
Continue full sensor sweeps. I   want all the information we can   gather.
Captain -- forward velocity down   point six percent.
Velocity down two point four   percent.
Mister Data?
We are moving through a dense   concentration of energy strands.
Can we go to warp?
The stress on the hull would be   too great...
Captain -- density appears to be   lower off the starboard bow.
Ensign, bring us to bearing   oh-three-oh mark five.
Aye, sir...
Forward velocity holding...
Steady as she goes...
Something wrong with the cake?
Pardon me?
When I see you with a piece of   chocolate cake... that hasn't been   touched... either the cake's no   good -- or something's bothering   you.
I'm sure the cake is fine. I've   just been thinking...
Let me guess... about a little   girl and her imaginary friend.
I'm just... wondering... if I'm   doing the right thing.
How so?
I know the best thing to do is   to gradually wean her away from   her fantasy... And today she did   meet some new friends, and had   a good time with them.
But?
But... at the same time, I can't   help wondering if I'm stealing   something from her... something   precious...
... a part of her childhood that   she'll never have again.
I don't know about that. I was   just telling Clara about my   imaginary friend.
Your imaginary friend?
Yeah -- a Tarcassian razor beast.   It protected me. I knew nothing   could ever hurt me as long as I   had that razor beast around.
Over the years, its body kind of   faded away. What was left was   more of an idea than a thing.       I don't talk to it nearly as much   as I used to.
You still talk to it?
All the time. When I get   scared... or confused... or I   need help. The way I see it, you   don't ever have to lose your   imaginary friend.
If it's something you need in your   life -- it'll be there.       It just might not be called an   imaginary friend anymore.
Ensign Sutter to Counselor Troi.
Go ahead, Ensign.
Would you come to my quarters?   I'm having a problem with Clara.
On my way.
She won't even go into her room.   She's terrified "Isabella" is   going to hurt her.
Clara... your father tells me   Isabella has been saying some very   bad things to you.
What did she say?
She said they were going to come   and kill everyone.
Who's going to come and kill   everyone?
The others... like her.
Did she say why?
I know you must be very   frightened. Sometimes what we   imagine can be just as scary as   something real.       But I promise you -- there's no   way Isabella can harm you or   anyone on this ship.
But she's not imaginary anymore.   She's real now. I can see   her...
You can see her... ?
Yes.
If I go with you and hold your   hand, will you go into your room?
I think so...
We'll make sure Isabella isn't   anywhere around. Alright?
Come on.
Do you see anybody?
Let's look under the bed...
Is she there?
Now... where else?
Is she behind here?
Maybe Isabella's gone home...
Anything there?
Maybe Isabella knows you're making   new friends now.
In fact, I'll bet she won't be   coming around as much anymore...
What about the closet?
Oh. Okay...
Anybody in here?
She was eleven, maybe twelve...   with blonde hair...
Clara...
Clara's sleeping. She's going   to be fine.
Her bioelectrical processes were   severely disrupted. It's like   the energy was pulled right out   of her body.
Captain... Clara told me her   imaginary friend was making   threats. She claimed that others   were on the way... and that they   were going to kill everyone on   the ship.
Picard to Lieutenant Worf.
Worf here.

We have established the presence   of what appears to be an alien   entity on board.       It seems the entity has manifested   itself in the form of a twelve-   year-old girl who has been seen   with Clara Sutter. She has blonde   hair... blue eyes...
... and a blue dress? Yes sir,   I have seen her.
When?
Two days ago, near engineering.   She was with Miss Sutter.
Engineering... Security Alert,   Mister Worf. Be on the lookout.
Aye, sir.
She insisted on talking to you.
It's about Isabella...
What about her, Clara?
I think her feelings were hurt.   She said she liked me... that she   liked being with me. She was my   friend. She only got mean when   I stopped paying attention to   her...
Did she say when the others were   coming?
Thanks, Sweetie. Go back to bed   now... we'll handle this.
But Daddy...
Thank you, Clara. If we need   your help again, I hope we can   count on you.
Yes, Captain.
Captain Picard -- report to the   the bridge.
On my way.
Report.
Our speed is down by twenty-two   percent.
Strand density is ten times what   it was, Captain. We can't take   many more hits...
All stop.
Sir -- something is heading   toward us, bearing one-oh-three   mark oh-two-four.
On screen.
What is it?
It appears to be an energy   vortex... of highly complex   patterns. Very possibly a life   form.
Red Alert!
It is in direct physical contact   with the shields.
Shields dropping to seventy-five   percent... seventy-two percent...
The damn thing's feeding off   our shields. Data -- remodulate   the shield frequencies!
Aye, sir.       No effect.
Shields to sixty-four percent.
We have about eight minutes before   those things drain our shields.
Any ideas?
Isabella... Isabella...
Isabella... Don't you want to talk   to me? I'm not mad at you...

We know you've been on the ship   for some time now. We know you've   been posing as Clara's friend --   and that you've been threatening   her...       We can only assume there's a   connection between you and the   life-forms attacking our ship...
You are obviously an intelligent   being. There's no reason for   you to hide...
Talk to us. Or can you only   communicate by frightening a small   child?
I'm scared, Isabella...
Who are you?
I came here to determine whether   you were a threat to us. And to   examine the purity of your energy   sources.
Energy... is that why they're   draining our shields?
Yes. The emissions from your   graviton field generators are   far richer than our normal   sources of energy.
Picard to bridge. Report.
Shields are down to three percent.   We're diverting all available   power.
Acknowledged.
If it's energy you want, we can   provide it in other ways. You   needn't destroy us.
You should be destroyed. You are   cruel, uncaring creatures.
What makes you say that?
The way you treat Clara.
In what way did we mistreat her?
You wouldn't let her do what she   wanted to... or go where she   wanted to...
You mean where you wanted her to.
Why does that make a difference?
You were taking her to places that   were inappropriate -- even   dangerous.
I wouldn't have let anything   happen to her...
We had no way of knowing that.   We had no way of knowing you were   real. All we knew was that a   little girl's imaginary friend   was scaring her... threatening   her...
That was only after you tried to   keep her from being my friend.
I'm beginning to understand.   You've seen this ship... all of   us... from a unique perspective   -- a child's point of view. It   must have seemed terribly unfair   and restrictive...

As adults, we don't always stop   to realize how everything we say   and do shapes the impressions of   young people.       But if you are to judge us as a   people by the way we treat our   children... and I cannot think   of a better criterion... you must   understand how deeply we care for   them. When our children are   young, they cannot always   understand what might be   dangerous. Our rules are a way   to keep them from harm. Either   real or imagined.
This is part of the continuity   of the Human species. You see...   when Clara grows up, she will make   rules for her children... to   protect them... just as we   protect her.
Please don't hurt us.
If you still want to be my best   friend, I'd like it very much.
Status, Number One?
We're free of the strands. We'll   have full warp capability in   twenty minutes.
Notify all sections we'll be   leaving the area in one hour.
Sir?
Mister La Forge, I want you to   drive the warp engines to full   power, and direct a flow of energy   out into the nebula.
Aye, sir...
I came to say... I'm sorry I   frightened you.
It's okay.
And I misled you. I wasn't really   your Isabella.
For a while you were.
I never had a friend before.
I'm sorry I have to go away.
Do you think you'll ever come   back?
I hope so.
So do I.
